title: 114_hr5531
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Miscellaneous Maritime Transportation Amendments Act of 2016" and includes provisions related to position, navigation, and timing resilience and security. It also addresses compliance deadlines, oil spill disbursements auditing, vessel "Apollonia," and reimbursement for non-Federal construction costs of certain aids to navigation. SEC. 102. BACKUP GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM. Amends title 46, United States Code, by adding CHAPTER 807--POSITION, NAVIGATION, AND TIMING. The Commandant of the Coast Guard, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, will establish a land-based system as a backup for the Global Positioning System (GPS) to ensure reliable positioning, navigation, and timing signals in case GPS signals are compromised. The system will be wireless, terrestrial, and provide wide-area coverage. The land-based backup system for GPS will be terrestrial, provide wide-area coverage, deliver a precise signal, be synchronized with universal time, resilient, penetrate underground and buildings, deployable to remote locations, utilize existing Government long-range navigation system, involve private sector expertise, and work with other navigation systems. The Commandant of the Coast Guard, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, must provide a plan to ensure the implementation of an enhanced long-range navigation system within 3 years. This system will be available for public use at no cost and will incorporate necessary requirements determined by the Commandant. TITLE II--OTHER MATTERS

SEC. 201. DEADLINE FOR COMPLIANCE WITH ALTERNATE SAFETY COMPLIANCE PROGRAM.

Section 4503(d)(1) of title 46, United States Code, is amended to require fishing vessels, fish processing vessels, and fish tender vessels to comply with an alternate safety compliance program developed in cooperation with the commercial fishing industry after January 1, 2020, or the end of a 3-year period from the date the program is prescribed by the Secretary.

SEC. 202. OIL SPILL DISBURSEMENTS AUDITING AND REPORT. Section 1012 of the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended by repealing subsection (g) and making changes to subsection (l)(1) and (l)(2) regarding the reporting requirements for disbursements from the Fund. The report must now include a list of disbursements of $500,000 or more from the Fund in the preceding fiscal year. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include reporting requirements for disbursements from the Fund, including a list of disbursements of $500,000 or more in the preceding fiscal year and a description of how each use of the Fund meets the requirements. SEC. 203. VESSEL ``APOLLONIA''. The Secretary of the department operating the Coast Guard shall issue a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement for the vessel Apollonia. SEC. 204. REIMBURSEMENT FOR NON-FEDERAL CONSTRUCTION COSTS OF CERTAIN AIDS TO NAVIGATION. The Commandant of the Coast Guard may reimburse a non-Federal entity for costs incurred for a covered project, subject to conditions such as the project's necessity for safe marine transportation and meeting Coast Guard standards. The Commandant of the Coast Guard may reimburse a non-Federal entity for costs incurred for a covered project, subject to conditions such as project completion transfer to the Coast Guard, necessary permits, and meeting additional Commandant requirements. Reimbursements are limited to $5,000,000 per project and $5,000,000 per fiscal year, with the authority expiring four years after enactment. A covered project is defined as one carried out by a non-Federal entity. A project carried out by a non-Federal entity to construct an aid to navigation on a federally authorized navigation channel.
